  363, 444 S.E.2d 513, 514 (1994) (appellant was deemed to have abandoned issue 
  where he failed to provide any argument or supporting authority).Â  At any rate, 
  even if this argument were properly presented to this court, we agree with the 
  circuit court that, pursuant to Muir v. C.R. Bard, Inc., 336 S.C. 266, 
  297-98, 519 S.E.2d 583, 599-600 (Ct. App. 1999), Smurfit-Stone is not entitled 
  to a credit for the payments because there is no evidence of record that the 
  accident and sickness benefits were made with reference to liability under the

In like summary fashion, Smurfit-Stone further asserts it 
  is entitled to a credit for all benefits Eaddy received from past workersâ€™ compensation 
  injuries because he is only entitled to â€œcompensation for the degree of disability 
  which would have resulted had he not suffered from prior hernias pursuant to 
  S.C. Code Ann. Â§Â§ 42-9-150, 42-9-160, and 42-9-170.â€Â  Assuming arguendo that 
  Smurfit-Stone has not abandoned this issue based on its conclusory argument, 
  we find no merit to its position.
South Carolina Code Ann. Â§ 42-9-150 provides:

If an employee has a permanent disability or has 
  sustained a permanent injury in service in the Army or Navy of the United 
  States or in another employment other than that in which he receives a subsequent 
  permanent injury by accident, such as specified in Â§ 42-9-30 or the second 
  paragraph of Â§ 42-9-10 he shall be entitled to compensation only for the degree 
  of disability which would have resulted from the later accident if the earlier 
  disability or injury had not existed, except that such employee may receive

S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 42-9-150 (1985) (emphasis added).Â  
  As noted by the circuit court, pursuant to this statute, an employer would only 
  be entitled to credit for previous awards of workersâ€™ compensation benefits 
  involving permanent disability.Â  There is no evidence of record, however, that 
  Eaddy ever sustained a previous permanent injury or received any permanent benefits 
  for such an injury.Â  The only evidence of any prior workersâ€™ compensation benefits 
  received by Eaddy were temporary total benefits paid by Smurfit-Stone.Â  Neither 
  is there evidence that Eaddy sustained a previous injury in service in the Army 
  or Navy or in another employment besides that of Smurfit-Stone.Â  Accordingly, 
  this statute is inapplicable to the present situation.
South Carolina Code Ann. Â§ 42-9-160 provides:

If an employee receives an injury for which compensation is 
  payable while he is still receiving or entitled to compensation for a previous 
  injury in the same employment, he shall not at the same time be entitled 
  to compensation for both injuries, unless the later injury be a permanent 
  injury such as specified in Â§ 42-9-30 or the second paragraph ofÂ  Â§ 42-9-10, 
  but he shall be entitled to compensation for that injury and from the time of 
  that injury which will cover the longest period and the largest amount payable

S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 42-9-160 (1985) (emphasis added).Â  We first 
  note this statute is inapplicable as there is no evidence Eaddy was â€œstill receiving 
  or entitled to compensationâ€ for his previous hernias.Â  Further, Eaddy would 
  fall under the exception of the provision since his latter hernia has been determined 
  to be a permanent injury.
Finally, South Carolina Code Ann. Â§ 42-9-170 provides in 
  pertinent part:

If an employee receives a permanent injury as specified 
  in Â§ 42-9-30 or the second paragraph of Â§ 42-9-10 after having sustained 
  another permanent injury in the same employment, he shall be entitled to

S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 42-9-170 (1985) (emphasis added).Â  Again, 
  because Eaddy did not suffer a permanent injury from the previous hernias, this

Accordingly, we find no error in the circuit courtâ€™s refusal 
  to find Smurfit-Stone was entitled to any credit for accident and sickness benefits

IV.Â Â Â  Commissionâ€™s Order
Smurfit-Stone next contends that the circuit court 
  erred in affirming the Commissionâ€™s order, alleging the order violated the South 
  Carolina Administrative Procedures Act (Act).Â  We disagree.
The Act provides, in pertinent part:

A final decision or order adverse to a party in a contested 
  case shall be in writing or stated in the record.Â  A final decision shall include 
  findings of fact and conclusions of law, separately stated.Â  Findings of fact,

S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 1-23-350 (1986).Â  Here, Smurfit-Stone contends 
  that the Commissionâ€™s order, which generally affirmed the single commissioner, 
  lacked separately stated findings of fact and conclusions of law.Â  It also contends 
  the order lacked an explicit statement of the underlying facts supporting the 
  Commissionâ€™s findings, as well as separately stated conclusions of law.Â  We 
  find this argument unavailing.
The Commission incorporated the single commissionerâ€™s 
  order by reference as if set forth verbatim within the Commissionâ€™s order.Â  
  The Commissionâ€™s order stated, in part:

[W]e, the appellate panel have reviewed the Award and weighed 
  the evidence as presented at the initial hearing.Â  We have also considered all

After careful review in the instant case, the appellate panel 
  of the [Commission] has determined that all of the Hearing Commissionerâ€™s Findings 
  of Fact and Rulings of Law are correct as stated.Â  We find that such Findings 
  of Fact and Conclusions of Law are hereby included in this Order 
  by reference, and by such reference, 
  the requirements of Baldwin v. James River Corporation, 304 SC 485, 405 SE2d4, 
  (sic) as well as Sections 42-17-40 and 1-23-350 of the South Carolina Code of 
  Laws have been met.Â  

The opinion also contained a footnote that stated:

It should be noted that the findings of fact and conclusions 
  of law as contained in the single commissionerâ€™s order are specifically referenced

We find the Commissionâ€™s incorporation of the single 
  commissionerâ€™s findings of fact and conclusions of law by reference provided 
  the circuit court with sufficiently definite and detailed findings to allow

For the foregoing reasons, the decision of the circuit court is
AFFIRMED.

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
Thomas Trancik, M.D., P.A.,       
Appellant,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
USAA Insurance Company & Rosemary
Wiggs,        Respondents.
      
    
  


Appeal From Richland County
L. Henry McKellar, Circuit Court Judge

Opinion No. 3644
Heard February 13, 2003 â€“ Filed May 
  27, 2003

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Robert W. Buffington, of Columbia, for Appellant.
Paul C. Ballou, of Columbia, for Respondent.
      
    
  


HOWARD, J.:Â  Thomas Trancik, M.D., P.A. 
  (â€œTrancikâ€) [1]  brought this 
  action for breach of contract and violation of the Unfair Trade Practices Act 
  (â€œUTPAâ€), alleging USAA Insurance Company (â€œUSAAâ€) failed to honor an assignment 
  of settlement proceeds executed by his patient, Rosemary Wiggs, in connection 
  with medical treatment she received following a motor-vehicle collision with 
  USAAâ€™s insured.Â  The trial court dismissed the suit, ruling Trancik failed to 
  state a claim for relief because no contractual privity with USAA existed.Â  
  We affirm.
FACTS
Trancik performed surgery on Wiggs for injuries she received in 
  an automobile accident.Â  Prior to surgery, Wiggs executed an assignment, which 
  states in relevant part:

I Rose Mary Wiggs, hereby guarantee payment of all charges 
  incurred . . . and hereby assign any medical insurance . . . or settlement 
  proceeds due because of liability of a third party by any party, organization 
  or insurance company . . . .

.Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  .Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  .

In the event the undersigned is entitled to physician or 
  physicians benefits of any type whatsoever arising out of any policy of insurance 
  insuring the patient or any party liable to patient, said benefits are hereby 
  assigned to Physician for application on patientâ€™s bill, and it is agreed that 
  the Physician may receipt for any such payment and such payment shall discharge 
  the said insurance company of any and all obligations under the policy to the 
  extent of such payment, the undersigned and/or patient being responsible for 
  charges not covered by this assignment.

Subsequently, Wiggs sued the at-fault driver, who referred 
  the matter to her insurance carrier, USAA.Â  Trancik sent the assignment to USAA, 
  and USAA acknowledged receipt of it.Â  USAA then settled Wiggsâ€™ claim, sending 
  payment directly to her.Â  Wiggs did not pay Trancik.  
Trancik brought this suit against USAA, 
  claiming the payment of settlement proceeds directly to Wiggs breached the assignment 
  contract and violated the UTPA.Â  The trial court dismissed both causes of action.Â  
  Trancik appeals the dismissal of his breach of contract claim, arguing the trial 
  court improperly concluded he lacked contractual privity with USAA.Â  We affirm.
STANDARD OF REVIEW
A trial court must dismiss a claim pursuant to 
  Rule 12(b)(6) of the South Carolina Rules of Civil Procedure, if the pleadings, 
  when taken in the light most favorable to the plaintiff, fail to allege sufficient 
  facts to constitute a cause of action. See Woodell ex rel. Allen v. 
  Marion Sch. Dist. One, 307 S.C. 297, 298, 414 S.E.2d 794, 794 (Ct. App. 
  1992).Â  However, the motion cannot be granted if the facts, and their reasonable 
  inferences, demonstrate the plaintiff could prevail on a theory of the case.Â  
  See Brown v. Leverette, 291 S.C. 364, 366, 353 S.E.2d 697, 698 
  (1987).
LAW/ANALYSIS
Trancik argues the trial court erred by granting 
  USAAâ€™s motion to dismiss.Â  He contends contractual privity existed between Trancik 
  and USAA by virtue of the assignment contract.Â  We disagree.
According to the complaint, two contracts existed:Â  
  the insurance contract between USAA and the at-fault driver and an assignment 
  contract between Wiggs and Trancik. Trancikâ€™s complaint alleges USAA breached 
  the assignment contract because Wiggs assigned her right to the insurance proceeds 
  to him, USAA had notice of the assignment, and USAA failed to pay the insurance 
  proceeds directly to him.
Trancik argues USAAâ€™s receipt of the assignment 
  contract was sufficient to create contractual privity with USAA, citing Gray 
  v. State Farm Auto. Ins. Co., 327 S.C. 646, 491 S.E.2d 272 (Ct. App. 1997) 
  to support this contention.Â  We disagree with Trancikâ€™s reading of the case.
In Gray, two chiropractors obtained assignments from 
  patients stating any money collected from the patientsâ€™ insurance carriers was 
  assigned to the chiropractors.Â  The assignments did not include claims against 
  third-party carriers.Â  The chiropractors sent these assignments to third-party-insurance 
  companies, which refused to honor them.Â  As in this case, the patients failed 
  to pay the chiropractors, and the chiropractors sued the third-party-insurance 
  companies, claiming they breached the assignment contract between the chiropractors 
  and their patients.Â  
This Court ruled no contractual privity existed between 
  the chiropractors and the third-party-insurance companies, noting the assignments 
  did not purport to cover the patientsâ€™ claims against third parties or their 
  carriers.Â  The language of the purported assignments applied only to the patientsâ€™ 
  insurance carriers, not third-party carriers. Id. at 650, 491 S.E.2d 
  at 274.
Because the Gray court noted the plain language 
  of the assignments did not include claims against third-party insurers, the 
  Court did not consider whether such wording would create an obligation on the 
  part of a third-party insurer.Â  Gray held, as a matter of contract construction, 
  the chiropractors failed to allege a cause of action because third-party carriers 
  were not mentioned in the assignment.Â  However, Gray does not provide 
  that contractual privity is established merely by including third-party-insurance 
  claims in the assignment.Â  Thus, this case is inapposite. [2] Â  Furthermore, we believe Trancikâ€™s position is untenable.
South Carolina contract law carries a presumption that an 
  individual who is not a party to a contract lacks privity to enforce it.Â  See 
  Touchberry v. City of Florence, 295 S.C. 47, 48-49, 367 S.E.2d 149, 150 
  (1988).Â  By the same token, an individual who is not a party to a contract generally 
  cannot be liable for its breach.Â  See Holder v. Haskett, 283 S.C. 
  247, 251, 321 S.E.2d 192, 194 (Ct. App. 1984).
The only parties to the assignment contract are Trancik and 
  Wiggs.Â  USAA is not a party to it.Â  Thus, unless USAAâ€™s insurance policy establishes 
  contractual privity with Wiggs or Trancik, no basis exists upon which USAA can 
  be held liable for breach of the assignment contract.Â  See Holder, 
  283 S.C. at 251, 321 S.E.2d at 194 (holding an individual who is not a party 
  to a contract cannot be liable for its breach).
Under the common law, â€œno privity [of contract exists] between 
  an injured person and the tortfeasorâ€™s liability insurer, and the injured person 
  has no right of action at law against the insurer.â€Â  44 Am. Jur. 2d Insurance 
  Â§ 1445 (1982); see Major v. Natâ€™l Indem. Co., 267 S.C. 517, 520, 
  229 S.E.2d 849, 850 (1976) (holding â€œ[a]t common law, no right to maintain suit 
  directly against the insurer existed absent privity of contract between the 
  claimant and the insuredâ€); McPherson v. Michigan Mut. Ins. Co., 306 
  S.C. 456, 464, 412 S.E.2d 445, 449 (Ct. App. 1991) (holding the insured clients 
  of an insured party were not in contractual privity with insuredâ€™s reinsurance 
  company because they were not a party to the reinsurance contract), affâ€™d 
  as modified by, 310 S.C. 316, 426 S.E.2d 770 (1993) (addressing whether 
  the injured party could sue the tortfeasorâ€™s insurance company, pursuant to 
  the policy, and not addressing whether the insured party could sue the reinsurance 
  company).
Third-party-liability-insurance contracts are generally indemnity 
  contracts whereby the insurer, or the first party, agrees to pay the insured, 
  or the second party, the amount of any damages the insured may become legally 
  liable to pay a third party.Â  See Town of Winnsboro v. Wiedeman-Singleton, 
  Inc., 303 S.C. 52, 56, 398 S.E.2d 500, 502 (Ct. App. 1990); see also 
  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 38-77-140 (2002) (â€œNo automobile insurance policy may be issued 
  . . . unless it contains a provision insuring the persons defined as insured 
  against loss from liability imposed by law for damages arising out of the ownership, 
  maintenance, or use of . . . [motor vehicles].â€).Â Â  Thus, the third party, or 
  the incidental beneficiary, does not have a contractual relationship with the 
  insurer and cannot maintain an action against the insurer for breach of the 
  insurance contract.Â  See Bob Hammond Constr. Co. v. Banks Constr. 
  Co., 312 S.C. 422, 424, 440 S.E.2d 890, 891 (Ct. App. 1994) (holding a third 
  person not in contractual privity with the contracting parties has no right 
  to enforce a contract unless the contracting parties intended to create a direct, 
  rather than an incidental or consequential, benefit to that third person); see 
  also Kleckley v. Northwestern Natâ€™l Cas. Co., 338 S.C. 131, 136, 
  526 S.E.2d 218, 220 (2000) (holding an injured third party could not assert 
  a bad faith claim against a tortfeasorâ€™s insurance company because the injured 
  party was not a party to the contract); Major, 267 S.C. at 520, 229 S.E.2d 
  at 850.
In this case, Trancik does not claim the insurance 
  contract is anything but an indemnity contract. [3] Â  Furthermore, Trancik does not 
  assert that he or Wiggs is a third-party, as opposed to an incidental, beneficiary 
  of the insurance contract.Â  Thus, Trancik has not alleged a basis upon which 
  to assert the existence of contractual privity between Wiggs and USAA.Â  See 
  44 Am. Jur. 2d Insurance Â§ 1445 (1982); Major, 267 S.C. at 520, 
  229 S.E.2d at 850; McPherson, 306 S.C. at 464, 412 S.E.2d at 449.Â  
Because Wiggs had no contractual privity with USAA, 
  Trancik received no greater right from Wiggs through her assignment.Â  See 
  Singletary v. Aetna Cas. & Sur. Co., 316 S.C. 199, 201, 447 S.E.2d 
  869, 870 (Ct. App. 1994) (holding an â€œassignee . . . stands in the shoes of 
  its assignorâ€); Rosemond v. Campbell, 288 S.C. 516, 522, 343 S.E.2d 641, 
  645 (Ct. App. 1986) (â€œAt common law, an assigneeâ€™s rights can be no greater 
  than those of his assignor.â€).Â  Therefore, notwithstanding the obligations incurred 
  by Wiggs pursuant to the assignment contract, mere notification of the assignment 
  was insufficient to contractually bind USAA.Â  Taking Trancikâ€™s well-pled allegations 
  as true, USAA was not in privity of contract with Wiggs or Trancik and was not 
  a party to the assignment.Â  Therefore, USAA had no contractual duty to abide 
  by its terms.
CONCLUSION
Based on the foregoing, the decision of the trial court is 
 AFFIRMED.  [4] 
 HUFF and STILWELL, JJ., concur.

 
   
    [1]  Although Thomas Trancik, M.D., P.A. is a separate legal entity, we 
    refer to the Appellant as Trancik in his individual capacity for ease of writing.

 
   
    [2]  Trancik also argues that the following cases support his position:Â  
    Dunbar v. Johnston, 170 S.C. 160, 169 S.E. 846 (1933), Thomasson 
    v. Ocean Point Gulf, Inc., 300 S.C. 29, 386 S.E.2d 282 (Ct. App. 1989), 
    and Southern Gen. Factors, Inc. v. Parker Concrete Pile Co., 236 F. 
    Supp. 103 (D.S.C. 1964).Â  However, these cases are equally inapposite because 
    they apply to assignments of first-party benefits.

 
   [3]  The USAA insurance policy is not included in the 
    record on appeal.

 
   
    [4]  The trial court also ruled the assignment was unenforceable because, 
    if valid, it would place an undue burden on USAA.Â  Because we agree with the 
    trial courtâ€™s ruling no contractual privity existed, we need not reach this 
    issue.
